page.title: 19CORN MILL, YSTRAD
page.content: {MELIN YR OM }(Known as Melynydd Dee in 1633) The Corn Mill - a focal point in local history - was probably set up by the Cisterian Monks of Penrhys who up until the early 14th century farmed sheep on their land. The wool would have been taken to the Tonypandy Fulling Mill for washing whilst the harvested corn would be ground into flour at Ystrad. The mill was situated in what was known as the Home Hamlet (as in the 1844 Tythe Map). The old mill wheel can be found at the bottom of Penrhys Road in front of St. Stephen'S Church. When Baptist Churches were being established, members were baptized in the Mill's water. Mill Street, Ystrad commemorates the Mill.
